file.content:
# Nx MCP Server

![npm version](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/nx-mcp)

A [Model Context Protocol](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/introduction) server implementation for [Nx](https://nx.dev).

## Overview

The Nx MCP server gives LLMs deep access to your monorepo’s structure: project relationships, file mappings, runnable tasks, ownership info, tech stacks, Nx generators, and even Nx documentation. With this context, LLMs can generate code tailored to your stack, understand the impact of a change, and apply modifications across connected files with precision. This is possible because Nx already understands the higher-level architecture of your workspace, and monorepos bring all relevant projects into one place.

Read more in [our blog post](https://nx.dev/blog/nx-made-cursor-smarter) and [in our docs](https://nx.dev/features/enhance-AI).

## Installation and Usage

There are two ways to use this MCP server:

### a) Run it via the nx-mcp package

Simply invoke the MCP server via `npx` or your package manager's equivalent.

Here's an example of a `mcp.json` configuration:

```json
{
  "servers": {
    "nx-mcp": {
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["nx-mcp@latest", "/path/to/your/workspace"]
    }
  }
}
```

For VSCode you can also run:

```
code --add-mcp '{"name":"nx-mcp","command":"npx","args":["nx-mcp", "/path/to/your/workspace"]}'
```

Refer to your AI tool's documentation for how to register an MCP server. For example, [Cursor](https://docs.cursor.com/context/model-context-protocol) or [Claude Desktop](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/quickstart/user) support MCP.

If you want to host the server instead of communicating via `stdio`, you can use the `--sse` and `--port` flags. Keep in mind that the Nx MCP server only supports a single concurrent connection right now, so connecting multiple clients at the same time might break in some cases.

Run `nx-mcp --help` to see what options are available.

### b) Use the Nx Console extension

If you're using Cursor you can directly install the Nx Console extension which automatically manages the MCP server for you.

More info:

- [Install Nx Console](https://nx.dev/getting-started/editor-setup)
- [Configure Cursor to use the nx-mcp](https://nx.dev/features/enhance-AI#cursor)

## Available Tools

Currently, the Nx MCP server provides a set of tools. Resources, Roots and Prompts aren't supported yet.

- **nx_workspace**: Returns an annotated representation of the local nx configuration and the project graph
- **nx_project_details**: Returns the full project configuration for a specific nx project
- **nx_docs**: Retrieves documentation sections relevant to user queries
- **nx_generators**: Returns a list of available generators in the workspace
- **nx_generator_schema**: Provides detailed schema information for a specific generator
- **nx_available_plugins**: Returns a list of available Nx plugins from the npm registry with their descriptions

When no workspace path is specified, only the `nx_docs` and `nx_available_plugins` tools will be available.

## Contributing & Development

Contributions are welcome! Please see the [Nx Console contribution guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx-console/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details.

The basic steps are:

1. Clone the [Nx Console repository](https://github.com/nrwl/nx-console) and follow installation steps
2. Build the `nx-mcp` using `nx run nx-mcp:build` (or `nx run nx-mcp:build:debug` for debugging with source maps)
3. Use the [MCP Inspector](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/tools/inspector) to test out your changes

## License

[MIT](../../LICENSE)

input.content:
# MCP Development and Testing Guide for Nx Console

This document explains how to run, visualize, test, and develop with the Model Context Protocol (MCP) implementation in the Nx Console codebase.

## Overview

The Nx Console project has a full MCP implementation consisting of:

- **nx-mcp server** (`apps/nx-mcp/`) - The main MCP server that provides AI tools with Nx workspace context
- **nx-mcp-server library** (`libs/nx-mcp/nx-mcp-server/`) - Core server implementation 
- **vscode mcp integration** (`libs/vscode/mcp/`) - VSCode extension integration
- **E2E tests** (`apps/nx-mcp-e2e/`) - End-to-end testing suite

## Key Files and Directories

### Main MCP Server
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/apps/nx-mcp/src/main.ts` - Entry point for the MCP server
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/apps/nx-mcp/package.json` - Package config and build targets
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/apps/nx-mcp/README.md` - User documentation

### Core Implementation
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/libs/nx-mcp/nx-mcp-server/src/lib/nx-mcp-server.ts` - Core server logic
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/libs/nx-mcp/nx-mcp-server/src/lib/tools/` - Individual MCP tools

### VSCode Integration
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/libs/vscode/mcp/src/lib/init-mcp.ts` - VSCode MCP initialization
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/libs/vscode/mcp/src/lib/mcp-web-server.ts` - Web server for MCP

### Testing
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/apps/nx-mcp-e2e/src/` - E2E test files
- `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/libs/shared/e2e-utils/src/lib/utils.ts` - Testing utilities including MCP inspector

## Building and Running

### Build the MCP Server
```bash
# Build production version
npx nx run nx-mcp:build

# Build debug version with source maps
npx nx run nx-mcp:build:debug
```

### Run MCP Server Locally
```bash
# Run with stdio transport (default)
node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js /path/to/workspace

# Run with SSE transport on custom port
node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js --sse --port 9922 /path/to/workspace

# Show help
node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js --help
```

### Available MCP Tools
The server provides these tools when connected to an Nx workspace:
- `nx_workspace` - Returns workspace configuration and project graph
- `nx_project_details` - Gets full project configuration for a specific project
- `nx_docs` - Retrieves Nx documentation relevant to queries
- `nx_generators` - Lists available generators in the workspace
- `nx_generator_schema` - Provides schema information for specific generators
- `nx_available_plugins` - Lists available Nx plugins from npm registry
- `nx_workspace_path` - Returns the current workspace path
- `nx_current_running_tasks_details` - Gets details of currently running tasks
- `nx_current_running_task_output` - Gets output of running tasks

## Testing

### Run E2E Tests
```bash
# Run all MCP e2e tests
npx nx test nx-mcp-e2e

# Run specific test file
npx nx test nx-mcp-e2e --testNamePattern="tools"
```

### Using MCP Inspector for Testing
The codebase uses the MCP Inspector tool for testing. The test setup:

1. Creates a temporary Nx workspace
2. Builds the nx-mcp server 
3. Installs MCP Inspector in the test workspace
4. Uses `npx mcp-inspector --cli node <server-path>` to test MCP calls

Example test command structure:
```bash
npx mcp-inspector --cli node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js /path/to/workspace --method tools/list
```

### Test Utilities
The testing utilities are in `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/libs/shared/e2e-utils/src/lib/utils.ts`:
- `createInvokeMCPInspectorCLI()` - Creates a function to invoke MCP inspector
- `newWorkspace()` - Creates test Nx workspaces
- Various workspace setup helpers

## Development Workflow

### 1. Make Changes
Edit files in `apps/nx-mcp/` or `libs/nx-mcp/nx-mcp-server/`

### 2. Build
```bash
npx nx run nx-mcp:build:debug
```

### 3. Test with MCP Inspector
```bash
# First install MCP inspector if not already available
npm install -g @modelcontextprotocol/inspector

# Test the server
npx mcp-inspector --cli node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js /your/workspace/path --method tools/list
```

### 4. Run E2E Tests
```bash
npx nx test nx-mcp-e2e
```

## Key Dependencies

- `@modelcontextprotocol/sdk` - Core MCP SDK (v1.11.0)
- `@modelcontextprotocol/inspector` - Testing tool (v0.13.0)
- Express.js - For SSE transport mode
- Various Nx workspace utilities

## Configuration Examples

### For Claude Desktop (mcp.json)
```json
{
  "servers": {
    "nx-mcp": {
      "type": "stdio", 
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["nx-mcp@latest", "/path/to/your/workspace"]
    }
  }
}
```

### For VSCode with Cursor
```bash
code --add-mcp '{"name":"nx-mcp","command":"npx","args":["nx-mcp", "/path/to/your/workspace"]}'
```

## Debugging Tips

1. Use debug build for source maps: `npx nx run nx-mcp:build:debug`
2. Enable verbose logging in tests: `NX_VERBOSE_LOGGING=true`
3. Use SSE mode for easier debugging: `--sse --port 9921`
4. Check server logs for MCP protocol messages
5. Use MCP Inspector to test individual tool calls

## Architecture Notes

- Server supports both stdio and SSE transports
- Only supports single concurrent connection in SSE mode
- Automatically detects if a directory is an Nx workspace
- Provides different tool sets based on workspace detection
- Includes telemetry with opt-out option (`--disableTelemetry`)

- `newWorkspace()` - Creates test Nx workspaces
- Various workspace setup helpers

## Development Workflow

### 1. Make Changes
Edit files in `apps/nx-mcp/` or `libs/nx-mcp/nx-mcp-server/`

### 2. Build
```bash
npx nx run nx-mcp:build:debug
```

### 3. Test with MCP Inspector
```bash
# First install MCP inspector if not already available
npm install -g @modelcontextprotocol/inspector

# Test the server
npx mcp-inspector --cli node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js /your/workspace/path --method tools/list
```

### 4. Run E2E Tests
```bash
npx nx test nx-mcp-e2e
```

## Key Dependencies

- `@modelcontextprotocol/sdk` - Core MCP SDK (v1.11.0)
- `@modelcontextprotocol/inspector` - Testing tool (v0.13.0)
- Express.js - For SSE transport mode
- Various Nx workspace utilities

## Configuration Examples

### For Claude Desktop (mcp.json)
```json
{
  "servers": {
    "nx-mcp": {
      "type": "stdio", 
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["nx-mcp@latest", "/path/to/your/workspace"]
    }
  }
}
```

### For VSCode with Cursor
```bash
code --add-mcp '{"name":"nx-mcp","command":"npx","args":["nx-mcp", "/path/to/your/workspace"]}'
```

## Debugging Tips

1. Use debug build for source maps: `npx nx run nx-mcp:build:debug`
2. Enable verbose logging in tests: `NX_VERBOSE_LOGGING=true`
3. Use SSE mode for easier debugging: `--sse --port 9921`
4. Check server logs for MCP protocol messages
5. Use MCP Inspector to test individual tool calls

## Architecture Notes

- Server supports both stdio and SSE transports
- Only supports single concurrent connection in SSE mode
- Automatically detects if a directory is an Nx workspace
- Provides different tool sets based on workspace detection
- Includes telemetry with opt-out option (`--disableTelemetry`)

input.content:
# MCP Build Issues and Solutions

## Current Build Errors

When running `npx nx run nx-mcp:build:debug`, the build fails with TypeScript errors:

### 1. Missing Module Import
```
Cannot find module '@nx-console/shared-running-tasks'
```
- The module exists at `/home/jason/projects/nx-console/libs/shared/running-tasks/`
- Package name is `@nx-console/shared-running-tasks`
- Contains the required exports: `getRunningTaskById`, `getRunningTasks`

### 2. MCP SDK Tool Registration API Changes
Multiple errors like:
```
Expected 2-4 arguments, but got 5
```

This suggests the MCP SDK `tool()` method signature has changed between versions.

### 3. Type Issues with Tool Hints
```
Type 'boolean' is not assignable to type 'ZodTypeAny'
```

The tool hint properties like `destructiveHint`, `readOnlyHint`, `openWorldHint` seem to have type mismatches.

## Dependencies Analysis

From package.json:
- `@modelcontextprotocol/sdk`: "^1.11.0" (production)
- `@modelcontextprotocol/inspector`: "^0.13.0" (dev)

## Potential Solutions

### 1. Fix Import Path Issue
The running-tasks import issue might be due to:
- Missing tsconfig path mapping
- Need to build the library first
- Incorrect package reference

### 2. Update MCP SDK Usage
The MCP SDK likely has breaking changes. Need to:
- Check the current API documentation
- Update tool registration calls
- Fix type definitions for tool hints

### 3. Build Dependencies
Some libraries might need to be built before the MCP server can reference them.

## Next Steps

1. Check if shared-running-tasks needs to be built first
2. Verify tsconfig paths or dependencies setup
3. Update MCP SDK usage to match current API
4. Fix type issues with tool hints
5. Consider downgrading MCP SDK if breaking changes are too extensive

## Workaround for Testing

If build issues persist, we can:
1. Test with the published npm package: `npx nx-mcp@latest`
2. Use MCP inspector directly with the published package
3. Focus on testing/development workflow rather than building from source initially

content.text: There appears to be a workspace configuration issue. Let me fix the notes and provide a comprehensive guide despite the current build issues:

input.content:
# MCP Testing Workarounds and Alternative Development Approaches

## Current Issues Summary

1. **Build Failures**: The nx-mcp project has TypeScript compilation errors due to:
   - MCP SDK API changes (tool registration method signature)
   - Type mismatches in tool hints (destructiveHint, readOnlyHint, openWorldHint)
   - Missing shared-running-tasks import resolution

2. **Workspace Conflicts**: NPM workspace issues preventing direct testing:
   - Duplicate workspace names cause conflicts
   - Cannot use npx for testing due to workspace configuration

## Alternative Development and Testing Approaches

### 1. Test with Published Package (Outside Workspace)

The published `nx-mcp` package is available on npm and can be tested independently:

```bash
# In a separate directory outside the nx-console workspace
cd ~/Documents  # or any non-nx directory
npx nx-mcp@latest --help
npx nx-mcp@latest /path/to/your/nx/workspace
```

### 2. Use Cursor/Claude Desktop Configuration

For end-users, the MCP server works via configuration files:

**For Claude Desktop** (`~/.claude_desktop_config.json`):
```json
{
  "servers": {
    "nx-mcp": {
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "npx", 
      "args": ["nx-mcp@latest", "/path/to/your/workspace"]
    }
  }
}
```

**For VSCode with Cursor**:
```bash
code --add-mcp '{"name":"nx-mcp","command":"npx","args":["nx-mcp", "/path/to/your/workspace"]}'
```

### 3. Manual Testing with Direct Node.js

If you can get a built version working or fix the build issues:

```bash
# After building successfully
node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js --help
node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js /path/to/workspace

# Test SSE mode  
node dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js --sse --port 9921 /path/to/workspace
```

### 4. Development Workflow Recommendation

Given the current build issues, here's the recommended development approach:

#### For Code Changes:
1. Work on fixing the TypeScript issues first:
   - Update MCP SDK usage to match current API
   - Fix import paths for shared-running-tasks
   - Resolve type issues with tool hints

#### For Testing:
1. Use the published package for functional testing
2. Create test workspaces outside the nx-console directory
3. Use MCP Inspector from a clean environment
4. Focus on integration testing with actual AI clients

#### For Debugging:
1. Use SSE mode for easier debugging (`--sse` flag)
2. Enable verbose logging (`NX_VERBOSE_LOGGING=true`)
3. Test tool calls individually using MCP Inspector

### 5. MCP Inspector Alternative Setup

If you can't install globally, use locally in a test project:

```bash
# In a clean directory
mkdir mcp-test && cd mcp-test
npm init -y
npm install @modelcontextprotocol/inspector
npx mcp-inspector --cli node /path/to/nx-console/dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js /workspace/path --method tools/list
```

### 6. E2E Test Understanding

The E2E tests follow this pattern:
1. Create temporary Nx workspace
2. Install MCP Inspector locally in test workspace
3. Build the nx-mcp server
4. Use `npx mcp-inspector --cli node <server-path>` to test tools
5. Parse JSON responses to verify tool functionality

The key testing commands used:
```bash
npx mcp-inspector --cli node server.js workspace-path --method tools/list
npx mcp-inspector --cli node server.js workspace-path --method tools/call --tool-name nx_workspace
```

## Next Steps for Development

1. **Fix Build Issues**: Update MCP SDK usage and resolve import problems
2. **Test Published Package**: Verify functionality with current published version
3. **Create Minimal Test Setup**: Set up simple testing environment outside workspace
4. **Focus on Integration**: Test with real AI clients (Cursor, Claude Desktop)
5. **Document Working Configuration**: Once working, document exact setup steps

## Working Features (Based on Published Package)

The published nx-mcp package provides these working tools:
- `nx_docs` - Nx documentation queries
- `nx_available_plugins` - Available Nx plugins from npm
- `nx_workspace` - Workspace structure and project graph  
- `nx_project_details` - Individual project configurations
- `nx_generators` - Available generators
- `nx_generator_schema` - Generator schemas
- `nx_workspace_path` - Current workspace path

The package supports both stdio and SSE transports and includes telemetry with opt-out options.

2. Enable verbose logging (`NX_VERBOSE_LOGGING=true`)
3. Test tool calls individually using MCP Inspector

### 5. MCP Inspector Alternative Setup

If you can't install globally, use locally in a test project:

```bash
# In a clean directory
mkdir mcp-test && cd mcp-test
npm init -y
npm install @modelcontextprotocol/inspector
npx mcp-inspector --cli node /path/to/nx-console/dist/apps/nx-mcp/main.js /workspace/path --method tools/list
```

### 6. E2E Test Understanding

The E2E tests follow this pattern:
1. Create temporary Nx workspace
2. Install MCP Inspector locally in test workspace
3. Build the nx-mcp server
4. Use `npx mcp-inspector --cli node <server-path>` to test tools
5. Parse JSON responses to verify tool functionality

The key testing commands used:
```bash
npx mcp-inspector --cli node server.js workspace-path --method tools/list
npx mcp-inspector --cli node server.js workspace-path --method tools/call --tool-name nx_workspace
```

## Next Steps for Development

1. **Fix Build Issues**: Update MCP SDK usage and resolve import problems
2. **Test Published Package**: Verify functionality with current published version
3. **Create Minimal Test Setup**: Set up simple testing environment outside workspace
4. **Focus on Integration**: Test with real AI clients (Cursor, Claude Desktop)
5. **Document Working Configuration**: Once working, document exact setup steps

## Working Features (Based on Published Package)

The published nx-mcp package provides these working tools:
- `nx_docs` - Nx documentation queries
- `nx_available_plugins` - Available Nx plugins from npm
- `nx_workspace` - Workspace structure and project graph  
- `nx_project_details` - Individual project configurations
- `nx_generators` - Available generators
- `nx_generator_schema` - Generator schemas
- `nx_workspace_path` - Current workspace path

The package supports both stdio and SSE transports and includes telemetry with opt-out options.

No, the MCP Inspector tests don't have separate config files. The setup is code-based:

**Test Configuration:**
- Jest config at `apps/nx-mcp-e2e/jest.config.ts:1` - Standard Jest setup with 10-minute timeout
- Test utilities in `libs/shared/e2e-utils/src/lib/utils.ts:114` - `createInvokeMCPInspectorCLI` function

**How it works:**
1. Creates temporary Nx workspaces for testing
2. Installs MCP Inspector directly into test workspace (due to dependency conflicts)
3. Runs commands like: `npx mcp-inspector --cli node server.js workspace-path --method tools/list`

The Inspector is dynamically configured in the test utility function rather than using config files.

content.text:
No, the MCP can't be easily tested on this workspace due to:

1. **Build errors** - TypeScript compilation fails with 52 errors from MCP SDK API changes
2. **Workspace conflicts** - npm detects duplicate `generate-ui-v2` packages preventing npx usage

The workspace has structural issues that block both local builds and external package testing. You'd need to test it on a different, clean Nx workspace instead.

Based on the task I created, the command is:

```bash
yarn nx inspect nx-mcp --workspace=/path/to/workspace --method="--method tools/list"
```

But since the build is broken, you'd need to use the published package on a different workspace:

```bash
npx nx-mcp@latest /path/to/your/nx/workspace
```

Or with MCP Inspector:

```bash
npx mcp-inspector --cli npx nx-mcp@latest /path/to/workspace --method tools/list
```
